urn:contentItem:6H5P-4C53-RRY8-D221-00000-00Findings in Electrical and Electronics Engineering Reported from Babol Noshirvani University of Technology (Deep Learning Approach for Forest Fire Detection: A CNN Classification Model on the DeepFire Dataset)2025-11-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisENGINEERING - ELECTRICAL AND ELECTRONICS ENGINEERINGFindings in Electrical and Electronics Engineering Reported from Babol Noshirvani University of Technology (Deep Learning Approach for Forest Fire Detection: A CNN Classification Model on the DeepFire Dataset)


2025 NOV 10 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Network Daily News -- Investigators discuss new findings in electrical and electronics engineering. According to news originating from Mazandaran, Iran, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forests play several vital roles in our lives and provide various resources."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Babol Noshirvani University of Technology: "However, in recent years, the increasing frequency of wildfires has led to the widespread burning and destruction of many forests and wildlands. Therefore, detecting forest fires and finding suitable solutions to address this issue has become one of the critical challenges for researchers. Today, with the advancement of artificial intelligence, forest fire detection using deep learning is an important method with the aim of increasing the efficiency of forest fire detection and monitoring systems. In this article, a method based on a type of convolutional neural network called Xception is proposed for classifying forest fire images. In this method, transfer learning technique is used on the proposed neural network and a new classifier is designed for the problem. Also, various hyperparameters have been used to optimize the performance of the proposed model."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The proposed method is performed on the DeepFire dataset, which contains 1900 images equally divided between fire and no-fire classes. The results obtained from the implementation of the proposed method show that this method with an accuracy of 99.47% has achieved a favorable performance in classifying forest fire images."
For more information on this research see: Deep Learning Approach for Forest Fire Detection: A CNN Classification Model on the DeepFire Dataset. Iranian Journal of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, 2025,21(4):3601-3601. (Iranian Journal of Electrical and Electronic Engineering - http://ijeee.iust.ac.ir/). The publisher for Iranian Journal of Electrical and Electronic Engineering is Iran University of Science and Technology.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Tara Sistani, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Babol Noshirvani University of Technology, Babol, Mazandaran, Iran. Additional authors for this research include Seyed Javad Kazemitabar.
Keywords for this news article include: Babol Noshirvani University of Technology, Mazandaran, Iran, Asia, Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Engineering, Networks, Neural Networks.

urn:contentItem:6H4V-7RF3-S96H-T0G8-00000-00Reports Summarize Physics Study Results from Forest Research Institute (Global Forest Fire Assessment Methods: A Comparative Analysis of Hazard, Susceptibility, and Vulnerability Approaches in Different Landscapes)2025-11-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisPHYSICSReports Summarize Physics Study Results from Forest Research Institute (Global Forest Fire Assessment Methods: A Comparative Analysis of Hazard, Susceptibility, and Vulnerability Approaches in Different Landscapes)


2025 NOV 06 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Physics Daily News -- Investigators discuss new findings in physics. According to news reporting out of Sofia, Bulgaria, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Forest fire risk assessment methodologies vary considerably, presenting challenges for adaptation to specific local contexts. This study provides a systematic analysis of forest fire assessment approaches across the Mediterranean basin, American, African, and Asian regions through a comprehensive review of 112 peer-reviewed studies published from 2015 to 2025."


Financial supporters for this research include Bulgarian Academy of Science (Ban) Forest Research Institute.
The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Forest Research Institute: "Statistical significance testing (Chi-square tests, p < 0.05) confirmed significant regional variation in methodological preferences and indicator usage patterns. Key findings revealed that Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis dominates the field (44% of studies, n = 49 ), with Analytical Hierarchical Process being the most utilized method (39 studies). Machine learning approaches represent 25% ( n = 28 ), with Random Forest leading significantly (22 applications). The analysis identified 67 indicators across seven major categories, with topographic factors (slope: 105 studies) and anthropogenic indicators (road networks: 92 studies) showing statistically significantly highest usage rates ( p < 0.001), representing a statistically significant critical gap in vulnerability assessment ( p < 0.01). Organizational factors remain severely underrepresented (a maximum of 14 studies for any factor), representing a statistically significant critical gap in risk assessments ( p < 0.01). Statistical analysis revealed that while Mediterranean approaches excel in integrating historical and cultural factors, American methods emphasize advanced technology integration, while Asian approaches focus on socio-economic dynamics and land-use interactions."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This study serves as a foundation for developing tailored assessment frameworks that combine remote sensing analysis, ground-based surveys, and community input while accounting for local constraints in data availability and technical capacity. The study concludes that effective forest fire risk assessment requires a balanced integration of global best practices with local environmental, social, and technical considerations, offering a roadmap for future forest fire risk assessment approaches in different regions worldwide."
For more information on this research see: Global Forest Fire Assessment Methods: A Comparative Analysis of Hazard, Susceptibility, and Vulnerability Approaches in Different Landscapes. Fire, 2025,8(10):380. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8100380.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Bojan Mihajlovski, Forest Research Institute, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, 1756 Sofia, Bulgaria. Additional authors for this research include Miglena Zhiyanski.
Keywords for this news article include: Forest Research Institute, Sofia, Bulgaria, Europe, Physics.

urn:contentItem:6H52-7J03-RRXD-F255-00000-00Research on Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Reported by Researchers at National University of Defense Technology (Integrated Optimization of Ground Support Systems and UAV Task Planning for Efficient Forest Fire Inspection)2025-11-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisAVIATION - UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLEResearch on Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Reported by Researchers at National University of Defense Technology (Integrated Optimization of Ground Support Systems and UAV Task Planning for Efficient Forest Fire Inspection)


2025 NOV 07 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Defense & Aerospace Daily -- Research findings on unmanned aerial vehicle are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting originating from Changsha, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "With the increasing frequency and intensity of forest fires driven by climate change and human activities, efficient detection and rapid response have become critical for forest fire prevention."


Financial supporters for this research include Major Program/open Project of Xiangjiang Laboratory; Science & Technology Project For Young And Middle-aged Talents of Hunan; National Natural Science Foundation of China; University Fundamental Research Fund; Costa.
The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from National University of Defense Technology: "Effective fire detection, swift response, and timely rescue are vital for forest firefighting efforts. This paper proposes an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-based forest fire inspection system that integrates a ground support system (GSS), aiming to enhance automation and flexibility in inspection tasks. A three-layer mixed-integer linear programming model is developed: the first layer focuses on the site selection and capacity planning of the GSS; the second layer defines the coverage scope of different GSS units; and the third layer plans the inspection routes of UAVs and coordinates multi-UAV collaborative tasks. For planning UAV patrol routes and collaborative tasks, a goal-driven greedy algorithm (GDGA) based on traditional greedy methods is proposed. Simulation experiments based on a real forest fire case in Turkey demonstrate that the proposed model reduces the total annual costs by 28.1% and 16.1% compared to task-only and renewable-only models, respectively, with a renewable energy penetration rate of 68.71%. The goal-driven greedy algorithm also shortens UAV patrol distances by 7.0% to 12.5% across different rotation angles."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "These results validate the effectiveness of the integrated model in improving inspection efficiency and economic benefits, thereby providing critical support for forest fire prevention."
For more information on this research see: Integrated Optimization of Ground Support Systems and UAV Task Planning for Efficient Forest Fire Inspection. Drones, 2025,9(10):684. (Drones - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/drones). The publisher for Drones is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/drones9100684.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Ze Liu, College of Systems Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha 410073, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Zhichao Shi, Wei Liu, Lu Zhang, Rui Wang.
Keywords for this news article include: National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, People's Republic of China, Asia, Aviation, Unmanned Aerial Vehicle.

urn:contentItem:6GPM-X9B3-S1KJ-22N2-00000-00China: Tianjin Forest Fire Prevention Office strives to ensure stable forest fire risk situation during key periods2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisChina: Tianjin Forest Fire Prevention Office strives to ensure stable forest fire risk situation during key periods

Key Highlights:

* The Tianjin Municipal Forest Fire Prevention Office has taken measures to ensure the stable forest fire risk situation during key periods.

* The office has organized video dispatch meetings and special consultations with various departments to analyze the forest fire risk situation and deploy related work.

* The office has issued risk warning letters and reminded relevant departments to closely coordinate and jointly do a good job in forest fire prevention.

Original Press Release:

Sept. 9 -- Ministry of Emergency Management of the People's Republic of China issued the following news release:

During key periods, the Tianjin Forest Fire Prevention and Suppression Command Office has firmly established bottom-line thinking and extreme thinking, kept a close eye on important time nodes, key areas and important targets, maintained a high level of vigilance, and taken effective measures to ensure that the forest fire prevention situation remains stable.

Comprehensively coordinate and coordinate forest fire prevention work. In mid-August, the Municipal Forest Fire Prevention Office held a video conference on forest fire prevention and control during the critical period. The conference brought together key units of the Municipal Forest Fire Prevention Office, including the Municipal Planning and Resources Department, Public Security Department, Industry and Information Technology Department, Civil Affairs Department, Culture and Tourism Department, Agriculture Committee, and Fire Department, along with the Forest Fire Prevention Offices of all agricultural districts and relevant units, to analyze the forest fire prevention work situation during the critical period and arrange related work. At the meeting, the Municipal Planning and Resources Department, Public Security Department, and Industry and Information Technology Department put forward specific requirements for relevant industry sectors during the critical period. The Municipal Forest Fire Prevention Office deployed forest fire prevention and control work for the city during the critical period, focusing on fire prevention publicity, hazard investigation and remediation, fire risk monitoring, patrols, and pre-deployment of teams and equipment. The office urged all agricultural districts and units to implement forest fire prevention work with a high sense of political responsibility, ensuring that there would be no smoke or fire during the critical period.

Focusing on key areas and areas, targeted reminders are being issued. The Municipal Forest Fire Prevention Office has issued a risk warning letter for key fire prevention areas with potential forest fire risks, urging relevant departments to closely collaborate and jointly implement forest fire prevention efforts. The Office has carefully identified key fire prevention and control periods, locations, and targets for fire hazards in various sectors, proposed practical and feasible prevention and control measures, coordinated collaboration among various departments, and organically integrated prevention and control measures across various industries, ultimately uniting the city's fire prevention and control efforts.

Closely monitor and jointly discuss and assess forest fire risks. Organize the city's meteorological, forestry, and public security departments to conduct special consultations on the forest fire risk situation during key periods. Comprehensively analyze weather and meteorological characteristics, forest conditions, and social conditions during these key periods, and comprehensively assess the city's forest fire risk situation. Distribute forest fire risk situation analysis materials to all agricultural districts and key members of the Municipal Forest Fire Prevention and Control Headquarters, reminding them to strengthen precautions against lightning fires and human use of fires, such as camping, picnics, and rituals, in light of the current forest fire risk situation. Carry out extensive and in-depth forest fire prevention publicity and education, strengthen crackdowns on illegal outdoor fire use, and strictly prevent human-caused fires.

We will strictly guard against and guard against fires, and make every effort to ensure emergency preparedness. During major events, the Municipal Forest Fire Prevention Office will implement enhanced on-duty and on-call work, strictly ensuring that leaders are on duty 24 hours a day and all staff are on duty at all times, to closely monitor the city's forest fire risk. We will conduct random inspections of fire video surveillance in agricultural areas and guide the forest fire prevention offices in these areas to organize and closely monitor key fire prevention and control units to ensure that fire sources do not enter the mountains or forests. We will also pre-dispatch various forest fire emergency rescue forces, including the National Fire Rescue Administration's Tianjin Mobile Team, aviation rescue crews, and professional and semi-professional forest fire prevention teams, to ensure that any fires can be extinguished quickly and efficiently, minimizing the impact and losses caused by the fires.

urn:contentItem:6H4V-7PJ3-S919-H32S-00000-00Research in the Area of Ecology and Conservation Reported from Hainan University (Is shortleaf pine regeneration declining under the current forest fire regime?)2025-11-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisLIFE SCIENCES - ECOLOGY AND CONSERVATIONResearch in the Area of Ecology and Conservation Reported from Hainan University (Is shortleaf pine regeneration declining under the current forest fire regime?)


2025 NOV 06 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Life Science Daily -- New research on ecology and conservation is the subject of a new report. According to news originating from Danzhou, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Shortleaf pine (Pinus echinata Mill.) has one of the widest geographic ranges of all pine species in North America and provides habitats for a large number of species."


Financial supporters for this research include U.S. Department of Agriculture; National Institute of Food And Agriculture.
Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Hainan University: "Shortleaf pine has decreased over time, and much of the decline has been considered recent and aligned with wildfire suppression. Shortleaf pine's decline within a relatively short ecological timeframe results in rapid losses of habitats and puts stress on the associated species to adapt to emerging habitats. Increasing interest is shown in the restoration of shortleaf pine, and a first step in restoration planning would be to understand its population dynamics. We provided a comprehensive evaluation of the spatio-temporal dynamics of shortleaf pine regeneration, indicative of its future population trajectories, across its broad range under the current forest fire regime using large time-series regeneration and forest fire data. Shortleaf pine regeneration was found to be largely stable across its approximate geographical range in the past two decades, contrary to the commonly perceived declining trend. Shortleaf pine regeneration increased in burned areas compared to unburned areas, but such increases gradually diminished over time."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The following general recommendations would help forest policy makers and conservation practitioners incorporate science- and data-driven solutions into restoration plans. • The return interval probably should be shorter than 15 years if prescribed fires are to be used to promote shortleaf pine regeneration; • Planting enables prompt restoration of shortleaf pine even in regions where it is currently rare or absent, but requires careful planning and application; • Thinning may be a viable solution to restore shortleaf pine in forests where it is a minor component, but may need to be accompanied by prescribed fire."
For more information on this research see: Is shortleaf pine regeneration declining under the current forest fire regime?. Global Ecology and Conservation, 2025,63():e03897. (Global Ecology and Conservation - http://www.journals.elsevier.com/global-ecology-and-conservation/). The publisher for Global Ecology and Conservation is Elsevier.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.gecco.2025.e03897.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Cen Chen, School of Tropical Agriculture and Forestry, Hainan University, Danzhou, Hainan 571737, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Kozma Naka, Shaik M. Hossain.

urn:contentItem:6H4V-7P53-RSN1-T12P-00000-00China Fire and Rescue Institute Researchers Provide New Data on Climate Change (Spatiotemporal Dynamics of Forest Fire Risk in Southeastern China Under Climate Change: Hydrothermal Drivers and Future Projections)2025-11-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEChina Fire and Rescue Institute Researchers Provide New Data on Climate Change (Spatiotemporal Dynamics of Forest Fire Risk in Southeastern China Under Climate Change: Hydrothermal Drivers and Future Projections)


2025 NOV 06 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Data detailed on climate change have been presented. According to news originating from Beijing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "Forest fire regimes are undergoing systematic reorganization under climate change, particularly in monsoon-human coupled ecosystems such as Southeastern China, where risk dynamics remain poorly quantified."


Financial supporters for this research include China Fire And Rescue Institute Scientific Research Project; Key Technologies For Preventing Safety Risks in The Construction And Operation of Photovoltaic Projects.
The news editors obtained a quote from the research from China Fire and Rescue Institute: "This study proposes a meteorology-driven machine learning model designed to assess long-term forest fire risk. Using kernel density estimation and standard deviational ellipse analysis, we assessed the spatiotemporal patterns of fire risk during the observational period and their future shifts across the SSP1-2.6 and SSP5-8.5 scenarios. The results indicate a significant overall decline in fire frequency from 2008 to 2024 (-467.3 fires/year, representing an annual average reduction of 10.8%, p < 0.001), which is attributed primarily to enhanced regional fire prevention and control measures, yet with a notable reversal after 2016 in Guangdong and Fujian. Fires are highly seasonal, with 74% occurring in the dry season (December-March). The meteorologically driven random forest model exhibited excellent performance (R2 = 0.889), validating meteorological conditions as key drivers of regional fire dynamics. It is projected that intensified warming (+5.5 °C under SSP5-8.5) and increased precipitation variability (+23%) are likely to drive pronounced northward and inland migration in high-risk zones."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Our projections indicate that by the end of the century, high-risk area coverage could expand to 19.2%, with a shift from diffuse to clustered patterns, particularly in Jiangsu and Zhejiang. These findings underscore the critical role of hydrothermal reconfiguration in reshaping fire risk geography and highlight the need for dynamic, region-specific fire management strategies in response to compound climate risks."
For more information on this research see: Spatiotemporal Dynamics of Forest Fire Risk in Southeastern China Under Climate Change: Hydrothermal Drivers and Future Projections. Atmosphere, 2025,16(10):1189. (Atmosphere - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/atmosphere/). The publisher for Atmosphere is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/atmos16101189.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Dapeng Gong, Forest and Grassland Fire Prevention and Control Research Center, China Fire and Rescue Institute, Beijing 102202, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Min Jing.

urn:contentItem:6H3J-8083-S86J-437W-00000-00Researchers at Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia Report Research in Engineering (Satellite-Based Forest Fire Mapping Using Group and Shuffle Network Embeddings)2025-10-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisENGINEERINGResearchers at Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia Report Research in Engineering (Satellite-Based Forest Fire Mapping Using Group and Shuffle Network Embeddings)


2025 OCT 31 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Engineering Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on engineering. According to news originating from Bangi, Malaysia, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "Forest fire mapping plays a vital role in environmental monitoring and disaster response."


Financial supporters for this research include Ministry of Higher Education, Malaysia, Through The Fundamental Research Grant Scheme; Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia Through Dana Padanan Kolaborasi-geran Pembiayaan Sepadan.
The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia: "While satellite imagery and deep learning have advanced automated fire detection, many existing approaches remain limited in accurately segmenting small-scale and irregular fire patches. The purpose of this study is to develop and evaluate GSDABNet, a novel deep semantic segmentation architecture for improved delineation of wildfire regions using Landsat-8 imagery. The model integrates depthwise asymmetric bottleneck (DAB) modules with a group-and-shuffle mechanism, enhancing feature diversity and spatial-spectral representation while reducing redundant global patterns. The methodological workflow includes preprocessing Landsat-8 imagery by selecting SWIR-1, SWIR-2, and Blue bands, building the proposed encoder-decoder framework with GS and DAB modules, and training on a publicly available global wildfire dataset. Model evaluation was performed using accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and mean Intersection over Union (mIoU), with additional ablation studies on GS placement, group size, and shuffle permutations to assess architectural contributions. Results show that the optimal configuration two groups with a (0,1,2,4,3) shuffle applied after the fifth DAB block achieved an mIoU of 0.6476, accuracy of 0.9957, and F1-score of 0.7201, outperforming multiple state-of-the-art benchmark models."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "These findings confirm GSDABNet as a highly accurate and computationally efficient framework for wildfire segmentation, contributing to improved early detection, effective risk mitigation, and sustainable forest management."
For more information on this research see: Satellite-Based Forest Fire Mapping Using Group and Shuffle Network Embeddings. IEEE Access, 2025,13():178387-178399. (IEEE Access - http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/servlet/opac?punumber=6287639). The publisher for IEEE Access is IEEE.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1109/ACCESS.2025.3621443.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Akhyar Akhyar, Department of Electrical, Electronic and Systems Engineering, Faculty of Engineering and Built Environment, Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Bangi, Malaysia. Additional authors for this research include Faiqah Nur Adlina Mohd Radzi, Siti Raihanah Abdani, Mohd Asyraf Zulkifley.
Keywords for this news article include: Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Bangi, Malaysia, Asia, Engineering.

urn:contentItem:6GXV-XRR3-RRYF-51TV-00000-00Data from Ottawa Advance Knowledge in Machine Learning (A Systematic Machine Learning Methodology for Enhancing Accuracy and Reducing Computational Complexity in Forest Fire Detection)2025-10-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisMACHINE LEARNINGData from Ottawa Advance Knowledge in Machine Learning (A Systematic Machine Learning Methodology for Enhancing Accuracy and Reducing Computational Complexity in Forest Fire Detection)


2025 OCT 09 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Robotics & Machine Learning Daily News Daily News -- Current study results on artificial intelligence have been published. According to news reporting from Ottawa, Canada, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Given the critical importance of timely forest fire detection to mitigate environmental and socio-economic consequences, this research aims to achieve high detection accuracy while maintaining real-time operational efficiency, with a particular focus on minimizing computational complexity."


The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Research & Development Department: "We propose a novel framework that systematically integrates normalization, feature selection, adaptive oversampling, and classifier optimization to enhance detection performance while minimizing computational overhead. The evaluation is conducted using three distinct Canadian forest fire datasets: Alberta Forest Fire (AFF), British Columbia Forest Fire (BCFF), and Saskatchewan Forest Fire (SFF). Initial classifier benchmarking identified the best-performing tree-based model, followed by normalization and feature selection optimization. Next, four oversampling methods were evaluated to address class imbalance. An ablation study quantified the contribution of each module to overall performance. Our targeted, stepwise strategy eliminated the need for exhaustive model searches, reducing computational cost by 97.75% without compromising accuracy."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Experimental results demonstrate substantial improvements in F1-score, AFF (from 69.12% to 82.75%), BCFF (61.95% to 77.91%), and SFF (90.03% to 96.18%) alongside notable reductions in False Negative Rates compared to baseline models."
For more information on this research see: A Systematic Machine Learning Methodology for Enhancing Accuracy and Reducing Computational Complexity in Forest Fire Detection. Fire, 2025,8(9):341. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8090341.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Marzia Zaman, Research & Development Division, Hegyi Geomatics, 102-30 Concourse Gate, Ottawa, ON K2E 7V7, Canada. Additional authors for this research include Darshana Upadhyay, Richard Purcell, Abdul Mutakabbir, Srinivas Sampalli, Chung-Horng Lung, Kshirasagar Naik.
Keywords for this news article include: Research & Development Department, Ottawa, Canada, North and Central America, Cyborgs, Emerging Technologies, Machine Learning.

urn:contentItem:6H2P-CYB3-S1DV-X1VS-00000-00Prince of Songkla University Researchers Have Published New Data on Geoscience (The synergistic use of AHP and GIS to assess factors driving forest fire potential in a peat swamp forest in Thailand)2025-10-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisSCIENCE - GEOSCIENCEPrince of Songkla University Researchers Have Published New Data on Geoscience (The synergistic use of AHP and GIS to assess factors driving forest fire potential in a peat swamp forest in Thailand)


2025 OCT 27 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- New research on geoscience is the subject of a new report. According to news originating from Songkhla, Thailand, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "Wildfires are a main reason of environmental changes in natural ecosystems."


The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Prince of Songkla University: "While prevention and suppression of forest fires are crucial components of a forest management plan, it is of paramount importance to support decisions with accurate and tangible information. Geospatial data have been a useful source in this aspect, and various techniques have been proposed to define the zonation of forest fire risk in fire-prone areas. In this study, we classify and map forest fire risk in a peat swamp forest in Khreng sub-district, Thailand. Geospatial, climatic, and topographic data (namely elevation, slope, rainfall, land use/land cover, normalized difference vegetation index, and proximity to rivers, settlements, and roads) are fed into the analytic hierarchy process (AHP) and Geographical Information System (GIS) methods to map the area into five fire risk categories. The results are validated based on 70 historic fire events. About 88.57% of the ground truth fire incidents occurred at locations characterized by our assessment as very high risk class and 11.43% in the high risk class."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "It is suggested that the synergy of geospatial data and GIS and AHP techniques yields useful and accurate fire zone maps, which may aid addressing future fire prevention measures and forest management of fire-prone areas."
For more information on this research see: The synergistic use of AHP and GIS to assess factors driving forest fire potential in a peat swamp forest in Thailand. Open Geosciences, 2025,17(1):741-6. (Open Geosciences - http://www.degruyter.com/view/j/geo). The publisher for Open Geosciences is De Gruyter.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1515/geo-2025-0888.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Nuthammachot Narissara, Faculty of Environmental Management, Prince of Songkla University, Hatyai, Songkhla, Thailand. Additional authors for this research include Jang Beomgeun, Stratoulias Dimitris.
Keywords for this news article include: Prince of Songkla University, Songkhla, Asia, Geoscience, Science, Thailand.

urn:contentItem:6GRN-SV73-RXRC-J1H1-00000-00Arequipa: Forest fire affects natural grasslands on Misti volcano2025-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisArequipa: Forest fire affects natural grasslands on Misti volcano


A forest fire on the slopes of the Misti volcano, in the district of Miraflores, has been registered since Saturday morning, with the possible causes still under investigation. This fact became more notorious in the evening hours due to the fact that the fire can be seen from different districts of the city.


According to the Regional Emergency Operations Center (Coer) Arequipa, this fire was reported at 11:45 hours, with no personal injuries or damage to life and health of people, but it did affect vegetation cover.
Due to the topographic conditions, control efforts were complicated in the afternoon hours. The Disaster Risk Management Manager of the Regional Government of Arequipa, José Luis Barrezueta, informed that they are still waiting for the report from the Provincial Municipality of Arequipa regarding the number of hectares affected.
Similarly, it was indicated that actions to control this forest fire are being coordinated with the District Municipality of Miraflores, the District Municipality of Chiguata and the Provincial Municipality of Arequipa, while the National Forest and Wildlife Service (SERFOR) is monitoring the effects on flora and fauna.
The authorities asked the population to remain calm and follow the recommendations while the fire is being extinguished.

urn:contentItem:6GR7-VP93-RSMG-X2V2-00000-00Quito registers a forest fire in San Juan protection zone2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisQuito registers a forest fire in San Juan protection zone


A forestfire was registered this Friday afternoon, September 12, 2025 in the SanJuan protection zone, in the northwest of Quito. The alert was issued at 14:42, when ECU911 cameras detected smoke in the sector.


Firefighters deployed helicopter and brigades on the ground.
The QuitoFire Department went to the site and, at 15:03, reported that they were attending a waste burning. At 16:10 it confirmed that the emergency was a forestfire. To deal with it, it deployed brigades on the ground and a helicopter that discharged water.
The institution said it also uses drones to monitor the progress of the flames and coordinate the extinguishingstrategy.
ECU 911 coordinates and maintains surveillance in the area.
ECU 911 indicated that the emergency was also evident in the sector of ElPlacer, within the HistoricCenter. From the ZonalOperationalRoom was coordinated the dispatch of resources and constant monitoring is maintained with video surveillancecameras.
Forest fires in Quito
In 2024, Quito faced one of the most severe forestfire seasons in recent years. The Quito Chamber of Commerce estimated economic losses of US$20 million. Between July and November of that year, 340 fires were reported, destroying 2,274 hectares of vegetation.
The FireDepartment attributed 99% of the fires to humanaction. The main causes were agricultural burning, garbage disposal, and campfires while hiking.
Reduction of cases in 2025
Between July 1 and September 1, 2025, there were 15 forestfires that affected 131.65 hectares in the Metropolitan District. During the same period, 615 waste burns were recorded, damaging 11.26 hectares.
Captain DianaVillacrés, head of the ForestFire Brigade, explained that the statistics show a downward trend. She pointed out that the reduction responds to training in schools, colleges, universities, rural parishes and vulnerableneighborhoods.
Climatic factors and control measures
The rains also had an influence in the reduction of fires. According to Inamhi, in July and August 2025 rainfall remained within normal levels in the Sierra, while in 2024 very low levels were recorded.
The Fire Department maintains temporary forestry brigades in risk sectors, forestrycabinets at strategic points and monitoring cameras to detect smoke. In addition, in coordination with the MetropolitanControlAgency, it carries out daily patrols to punish those who cause fires.

urn:contentItem:6GYP-T9F3-RV32-J221-00000-00University of Delhi Researchers Provide New Data on Artificial Neural Networks (Assessing forest fire vulnerability using artificial neural networks in Almora district, Uttarakhand, India)2025-10-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisARTIFICIAL NEURAL NETWORKSUniversity of Delhi Researchers Provide New Data on Artificial Neural Networks (Assessing forest fire vulnerability using artificial neural networks in Almora district, Uttarakhand, India)


2025 OCT 13 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Network Daily News -- New research on artificial neural networks is the subject of a new report. According to news reporting out of the University of Delhi by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Forests are vital to terrestrial ecosystems and they offer essential services for climate regulation and human welfare. However, the increasing trend in forest fires poses a significant threat to these ecosystems."


Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from University of Delhi: "This study aims to map and assess forest fire vulnerability zones within Almora district, Uttarakhand, India, using geospatial technologies and the Artificial Neural Network (ANN) technique. Twelve environmental indicators related to forest fire vulnerability, including elevation, slope, land use/land cover (LULC), Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), Vegetation Health Index (VHI), temperature, precipitation, humidity, wind speed, Land Surface Temperature (LST), and distance from settlements and roads, were considered. The study revealed that a strip running from northern to southern Almora, including Someshwar, Dwarahat, and Ranikhet, is highly vulnerable to forest fires. This region is characterized by moderate to high elevation, a moderate to steep slope, and well-connected roads and settlements, particularly in Dwarahat and Ranikhet tehsils. The central and southern parts of Almora also exhibit good road connectivity, dense human settlements, and receive moderate to low precipitation, all of which contribute to a higher fire risk. In contrast, the eastern and western parts of Almora, comprising northern Sult, northern Bhikiyasain, and Banoli tehsils, are significantly less vulnerable to forest fires."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "These areas have moderate slopes, low to moderate elevation, higher precipitation in the eastern parts, and lower precipitation in the western parts, making them comparatively less prone to fire incidents. Validation through the Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve confirmed the accuracy of the model, with an 82% area under the curve."
For more information on this research see: Assessing forest fire vulnerability using artificial neural networks in Almora district, Uttarakhand, India. Journal of the Bulgarian Geographical Society, 2025,53():67-86. The publisher for Journal of the Bulgarian Geographical Society is Bulgarian Geographical Society.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3897/jbgs.e159980.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Aditya Kumar, University of Delhi.

urn:contentItem:6H4V-7PJ3-S919-H2XG-00000-00Report Summarizes Biology Study Findings from University of Florence (Deciphering the Fate of Burned Trees After a Forest Fire: A Systematic Review Focused on Conifers)2025-11-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisLIFE SCIENCES - BIOLOGYReport Summarizes Biology Study Findings from University of Florence (Deciphering the Fate of Burned Trees After a Forest Fire: A Systematic Review Focused on Conifers)


2025 NOV 06 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Life Science Daily -- Current study results on biology have been published. According to news originating from Florence, Italy, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "Climate change is intensifying fire regimes, thereby challenging forest ecosystems and making it more difficult to predict the fate of burned trees. The significant ecological impacts of latent tree mortality remain poorly understood."


Funders for this research include National Recovery And Resilience Plan; European Union-nextgenerationeu.
Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from University of Florence: "In this study, we reviewed the scientific literature on latent tree mortality in conifer forests following wildfires or prescribed fires. A total of 2294 papers published between 2000 and 2024 were identified from Scopus and Web of Science databases. Using the PICO selection method, we included 16 relevant studies in the final analysis. These studies are based on field assessment, excluding remote sensing and controlled laboratory conditions. Our research revealed that latent mortality results from multiple forms of damage and environmental stressors that disrupt hydraulic function and carbon allocation, increasing tree vulnerability to secondary biotic and abiotic stressors. The discussion is structured around four thematic areas: physiology, ecophysiology, dendrochronology, and silviculture. This approach contributes to a deeper, interdisciplinary understanding of latent tree mortality."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "However, predicting it remains difficult, reflecting persistent knowledge gaps. Despite the limited literature on this specific field, our review highlights the need for integrated physiological indicators, such as sap flow, transpiration, nonstructural carbohydrates and glucose concentration, as well as long-term monitoring along many growing seasons to better assess tree survival after fire."
For more information on this research see: Deciphering the Fate of Burned Trees After a Forest Fire: A Systematic Review Focused on Conifers. Biology, 2025,14(10):1372. (Biology - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/biology). The publisher for Biology is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/biology14101372.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Alessandro Bizzarri, Department of Agriculture, Food, Environment and Forestry (DAGRI), University of Florence, Piazzale delle Cascine 18, 50144 Florence, Italy. Additional authors for this research include Margherita Paladini, Niccolo Frassinelli, Enrico Marchi, Raffaella Margherita Zampieri, Alessio Giovannelli, Claudia Cocozza.
Keywords for this news article include: University of Florence, Florence, Italy, Europe, Biology, Life Sciences.

urn:contentItem:6GNJ-3DY3-RS5H-31V7-00000-00Forest fire in Cañar consumes more than 287 hectares of vegetation2025-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisForest fire in Cañar consumes more than 287 hectares of vegetation


A forest fire has been active since August 27 in the La Carbonería sector, in Cañar. At least 120 people joined the fire control work in the area.


Activation of protocols for forest fire in Cañar
Since the forest fire alert was issued,the Secretariat of Risk Management activated protocols to try to control the fire.
Thus, joint actions were established with the Municipality of Cañar to establish an action plan to control the fire.
On Thursday, September 4, the forest fire is still active, so technical and logistical resources were activated, with advice to the cantonal COE.
In addition, the Austro Forest Fire Reinforcement Brigade (BRIF) was activated to support the work of controlling the flames.
In total, more than 120 people have joined the work on the mountain to try to extinguish the fire. However, the dry vegetation and the absence of rain, added to the winds, make the work difficult.
At the moment, these are the resources deployed at the site:

Cañar Firefighters: 20 people, 1 tango unit, 1 logistic, 1 ambulance, 2 motorcycles + 3 volunteers.

Communities: Quilloac (7), Zhizho (11), San Rafael (25), Yuracazha (2), Coreourco (6), Cuchucun (20).

GAD Cañar: 20 people

Health District: 9 people, 1 ambulance, 1 double-cabin pickup truck

Prefecture: 8 people, 1 vehicle


The Secretariat of Risk Management also informed that, in order to reinforce the suffocation work, personnel from the Cuenca Fire Department were incorporated. In addition, a pool of water was filled in the area, which will allow to supply with greater capacity and bring water directly to the fire area.

urn:contentItem:6GPK-Y623-RS3T-S3TS-00000-00Forest fire affects two districts in Huancayo2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisForest fire affects two districts in Huancayo


The hills do not stop burning. A forest fire consumed yesterday more than hectares of pastures in the annex of Paccha, in the district of El Tambo. The shepherds who were taking care of animals gave the warning to Serfor, said the person in charge of the technical forestry unit of this entity, Christian Quispe.


Although the area that was burning was extensive, the firefighters could not reach the area, since it was on the top of the hill, Christian Quispe said that the only thing left to do was to wait for the fire to go out naturally and not advance towards the population.
IT SPREADS. However, the fire continued to advance and reached the neighboring district of San Agustín de Cajas. In the area, the serenos and locals can be seen using branches to suffocate the fire, which threatened to reach the houses.
"The forest fire that started in Paccha spread to San Agustín de Cajas, in the area known as Alalá, there are some houses and the inhabitants dedicated to livestock have had to withdraw for the moment there are 20 hectares affected," said Juan Casas Roque, in charge of the sub-management of Citizen Security of San Agustín de Cajas.
Serfor reported that a resident may have set a fire to burn the pastures and it became uncontrollable. In addition, due to the dry weather and the winds, the fire flames spread uncontrollably.
He explained that if the wind blows into the wooded area it was feared that it could affect the trees and could even reach the population.

urn:contentItem:6GS3-RCC3-RS40-Y3JR-00000-00Forest fire affects Conunhueno hill in Padre Las Casas2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisForest fire affects Conunhueno hill in Padre Las Casas


A violent forest fire is affecting the Conunhueno hill, in the commune of Padre Las Casas, in the Araucanía Region.


According to preliminary information, the fire in the vegetation of the area started around 9:00 p.m., prompting the deployment of firefighters to combat the flames.
The organization deployed a total of five companies, which have had difficulties in their work, due to the problems of access to the affected place, where it is not possible to enter by vehicle.
Captain Eduardo Azócar, of the 4th Temuco Fire Company, said that "the first forest fire alarm was activated due to the great extension of the fire in the scrubland, which is difficult to access. The units can only reach a certain part and from there they have to work as infantrymen (on foot) with hand tools only".
Mayor Mario González expressed his concern for the electricity and telephone supply of Padre Las Casas, since the fire could affect the cables that supply the services.
"There is a creek where the fire got into. It is circumscribed, that's good. There are no houses, there are no dwellings, therefore, there is no effect on human beings. We are concerned about the issue of the cables, of the electric wiring", detailed the communal chief, in declarations collected by 24 Horas.
The fire has registered at least three outbreaks and can even be seen from the regional capital, the city of Temuco.
During the next few hours it is expected that other agencies will join in the fight against the flames, such as a technician from the National Forestry Corporation (Conaf).

urn:contentItem:6GSB-1DY3-RS85-340T-00000-00China: Anhui Province held a training course to enhance the professional capabilities of forest fire prevention and control in 20252025-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisChina: Anhui Province held a training course to enhance the professional capabilities of forest fire prevention and control in 2025

Key Highlights:

* The Anhui Province Forest Fire Prevention and Extinguishing Professional Ability Enhancement Training Class was held in Huoshan, Anhui Province.

* The training aimed to enhance the professional abilities of forest fire prevention and extinguishing personnel, with a focus on prevention, reduction, and rescue systems.

* The province has made significant progress in forest fire prevention and extinguishing, with a shift from wind-powered fire extinguishing to a combination of wind and water, with water as the main method.

Original Press Release:

Sept. 17 -- Ministry of Emergency Management of the People's Republic of China issued the following news release:

Recently, a training course to enhance professional capabilities in forest fire prevention and firefighting was held in Huoshan, Anhui Province. Bai Zhonghua, member of the Party Committee and Deputy Director of the Provincial Emergency Management Department, attended the opening ceremony and delivered a speech.

Bai Zhonghua pointed out that since last year, with the concerted efforts of the entire system and leveraging the opportunity of additional treasury bonds, a comprehensive monitoring and perception, early warning and response, command and dispatch, and rescue equipment system covering the entire region, all types of disasters, and the entire supply chain has been basically established. This has led to a comprehensive and leapfrog improvement in the prevention, mitigation, and rescue systems and capacity building at the provincial, municipal, county, township, and village levels. In the field of forest fire prevention and control, the problems of lack of monitoring methods, inaccurate early warnings, and untimely detection have been completely resolved. Firefighting methods have been completely transformed from wind-driven extinguishing to a combination of wind and water, with water as the primary method. This has played a vital role in ensuring and supporting the victory in the battle against forest fires last winter and this spring, and has laid a solid foundation for promoting the "five-pronged expansion" of forest fire prevention and control work during the 15th Five-Year Plan period.

Bai Zhonghua emphasized that all levels of government must integrate forest fire prevention and control into the grassroots emergency response system and capacity building, comprehensively consider, design, and promote them as a whole. The 15th Five-Year Plan project plan must be systematically and diversifiedly planned. Adhering to the principle of "integrated prevention and control," we must prioritize simultaneous and integrated planning of prevention and control projects, striving to have more projects included in the national planning system. We must unwaveringly advance the development of grassroots teams. Focusing on the requirements of "integrated response and firefighting, specialized and multi-skilled," we must tailor the development of a local forest firefighting team system that "effectively prevents fires at the source, quickly extinguishes small fires, tackles large fires with strong work style and skills, and ensures safety." We must continuously strengthen system mechanisms and operational capabilities. Focusing on the fundamental principles of vertical and horizontal coordination, and based on the 1311 command system for flood control and disaster relief, we must standardize and operationalize all elements of monitoring, early warning, emergency response, and command and dispatch. Through a flat structure and standardized operations, we will continuously improve the quality and efficiency of forest fire prevention and control. We must plan ahead and effectively carry out forest fire prevention and control efforts in the second half of the autumn and winter seasons. We will earnestly implement the instructions of the main leaders of the Provincial Party Committee and the Provincial Government, carefully organize various emergency preparedness work, and make every effort to "prevent". We will strengthen the responsibilities of the heads of industry departments at all levels and the supervisory responsibilities of relevant departments, and effectively form an overall synergy to ensure that the forest fire prevention and control situation in the province continues to be stable and positive.

This training session brought together experts and scholars with extensive practical experience from the China Fire and Rescue Academy, the State Key Laboratory of Fire Science at the University of Science and Technology of China, the Guangzhou Municipal Emergency Management Bureau, and the Anhui Mobile Team of the National Fire and Rescue Administration. They delivered lectures on forest fire organization and command, the application of "water-firefighting" techniques and tactics, and forest fire situations and prevention and control technologies. The training also included an exchange of experiences with grassroots personnel. Over 140 participants attended the training, including frontline commanders from municipal, county (city, and district) forest fire prevention and control command organizations, emergency response departments, township governments, and professional teams.

urn:contentItem:6GWK-2V83-RSH3-W0B3-00000-00North China Institute of Science and Technology Researchers Update Current Study Findings on Geoscience (YOLO-MC: An algorithm for early forest fire recognition based on drone image)2025-10-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisSCIENCE - GEOSCIENCENorth China Institute of Science and Technology Researchers Update Current Study Findings on Geoscience (YOLO-MC: An algorithm for early forest fire recognition based on drone image)


2025 OCT 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- New research on geoscience is the subject of a new report. According to news originating from Hebei, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forests not only provide important resources for the earth, but also play an important role in maintaining ecological balance. Once forest fires occur, they will pose a serious threat to human beings."


The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from North China Institute of Science and Technology: "As a convenient and high-definition remote sensing equipment, unmanned aerial vehicle provides effective support for forest fire monitoring. The early forest fire smoke flame target is small and the dynamic change is difficult to identify. In this study, a forest fire dataset is first constructed, and an early forest fire detection model, YOLO-MC, based on YOLOV8, is proposed. Lightweight backbone network MobileNetV3 is used to replace the original backbone. Convolutional block attention module attention mechanism is added to make the model pay more attention to local information connection. Bidirectional feature pyramid network and small target layer are introduced to dynamically assign weights to identify small targets. Dynamic head is used to improve the flexibility of model inspection. Generalized intersection over union is used as a loss function to improve the accuracy of target positioning."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Compared with the benchmark model, the accuracy and average accuracy of YOLO-MC are increased by 4.3 and 3.6%, respectively, and the number of parameters is reduced by 2 x 104, which indicates that YOLO-MC can improve the identification efficiency of early forest fires and realize the early detection of forest fires at the same time. It helps in identifying forest fires as early as possible and has certain practical significance."
For more information on this research see: YOLO-MC: An algorithm for early forest fire recognition based on drone image. Open Geosciences, 2025,17(1):1-12. (Open Geosciences - http://www.degruyter.com/view/j/geo). The publisher for Open Geosciences is De Gruyter.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1515/geo-2025-0875.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Liu Xiaoqian, North China Institute of Science and Technology, Hebei, 065201, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Chen Zhenguo, Jiang Wei.
Keywords for this news article include: North China Institute of Science and Technology, Hebei, People's Republic of China, Asia, Algorithms, Geoscience, Science.

urn:contentItem:6GRG-9T13-S0GH-P2F6-00000-00Forest fire in the San Juan protection zone in Quito mobilizes more than 70 firefighters2025-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisForest fire in the San Juan protection zone in Quito mobilizes more than 70 firefighters


A forest fire was recorded on the afternoon of Friday, September 12, 2025 in the San Juan protection zone, in the northwest of Quito. The alert was issued at 14:42, when ECU 911 cameras detected smoke in the sector.
The Quito Fire Department reported that, at 15:03, they were attending a waste burning. Minutes later, at 16:10, it confirmed that it was a forest fire. To deal with the emergency, they deployed ground brigades and a helicopter that discharged water.


Forest fire under constant monitoring
ECU 911 indicated that the emergency was also evident in the sector of El Placer, within the Historic Center. From the Zonal Operational Room was coordinated the dispatch of resources and monitoring is maintained with video surveillance cameras.
Do not miss to read: The elimination of diesel subsidy in Ecuador, how will it influence vehicle sales?
Quito Firefighters noted on their Twitter account that they use drones to monitor the advance of the flames and define the extinguishing strategy.
Forest fire with active outbreaks
On the morning of this Saturday, September 13, 2025, the institution updated that it continued in control work in San Juan. Three active outbreaks with flames were identified .
The helicopter began the aerial combat, whilemore than 70 personnel and 20 vehicles worked at the site.
Reduction of fires in 2025
In 2024, Quito recorded 340 forest fires that destroyed 2,274 hectares of vegetation, according to data from the Chamber of Commerce. The Fire Department attributed 99% of the cases to human action.
Between July and September 2025,the Metropolitan District reported 15 forest fires, a reduction compared to the previous year.

urn:contentItem:6GN4-5F03-S5NX-F0K7-00000-00New forest fire hits Quito this September 2nd2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisNew forest fire hits Quito this September 2nd


The Emergency Service ECU911 informed on Tuesday, September 2, about a new forest fire registered in a sector of Quito.
???? Forest fire in La Betania sector
ECU911 reported that the forest fire was verified through video surveillance devices at 10:30 today, in the La Betania sector, in Luis Tufiño and Gualaquiza streets, in the north of Quito.


From the 911 Operational Room, the mobilization of the Quito Fire Department contingent was coordinated in a timely manner.
Personnel of this emergency institution went immediately and found the flames on a hillside, so they activated the work of smothering the flames to prevent them from consuming all the vegetation on the hillside.
The fire departmentresponded with personnel and a firefighting unit.
In spite of the smoke generated by the fire, the traffic is still open on this road; however, it is recommended to drive with caution, as there is smoke and a Fire Department unit on the road.
Remember to call 911 immediately if you detect a column of smoke or a fire.
???? High daytime temperatures may contribute to the formation of forest fires
The Metropolitan EOC warns about the risk of heat stroke and dehydration, especially in vulnerable groups due to high daytime temperatures. Likewise, there may be higher consumption of water and electricity due to the use of cooling systems.
With these conditions, the probability of forest fires increases in some sectors, take precautions and do not burn in dry areas or light sparks.

Ultraviolet radiation remains at extremely high levels, so always use sunscreen.

Wear clothing that covers your skin, so you will be protected from radiation and the sun.

Stay hydrated

Keep rooms cool and ventilated

Pay more attention to children and elderly people

urn:contentItem:6GY2-WJB3-S6K0-7161-00000-00New Physics Findings from Northeast Forestry University Described (All-Weather Forest Fire Automatic Monitoring and Early Warning Application Based on Multi-Source Remote Sensing Data: Case Study of Yunnan)2025-10-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisPHYSICSNew Physics Findings from Northeast Forestry University Described (All-Weather Forest Fire Automatic Monitoring and Early Warning Application Based on Multi-Source Remote Sensing Data: Case Study of Yunnan)


2025 OCT 10 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Information Technology Daily -- New study results on physics have been published. According to news reporting out of Harbin, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Forest fires pose severe ecological, climatic, and socio-economic threats, destroying habitats and emitting greenhouse gases. Early and timely warning is particularly challenging because fires often originate from small-scale, low-temperature ignition sources."


Financial supporters for this research include National Key Research And Development Program of China; Fundamental Research Funds For The Central Universities.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Northeast Forestry University: "Traditional monitoring approaches primarily rely on single-source satellite imagery and empirical threshold algorithms, and most forest fire monitoring tasks remain human-driven. Existing frameworks have yet to effectively integrate multiple data sources and detection algorithms, lacking the capability to provide continuous, automated, and generalizable fire monitoring across diverse fire scenarios. To address these challenges, this study first improves multiple monitoring algorithms for forest fire detection, including a statistically enhanced automatic thresholding method; data augmentation to expand the U-Net deep learning dataset; and the application of a freeze-unfreeze transfer learning strategy to the U-Net transfer model. Multiple algorithms are systematically evaluated across varying fire scales, showing that the improved automatic threshold method achieves the best performance on GF-4 imagery with an F-score of 0.915 (95% CI: 0.8725-0.9524), while the U-Net deep learning algorithm yields the highest F-score of 0.921 (95% CI: 0.8537-0.9739) on Landsat 8 imagery. All methods demonstrate robust performance and generalizability across diverse scenarios. Second, data-driven scheduling technology is developed to automatically initiate preprocessing and fire detection tasks, significantly reducing fire discovery time. Finally, an integrated framework of multi-source remote sensing data, advanced detection algorithms, and a user-friendly visualization interface is proposed."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This framework enables all-weather, fully automated forest fire monitoring and early warning, facilitating dynamic tracking of fire evolution and precise fire line localization through the cross-application of heterogeneous data sources. The framework's effectiveness and practicality are validated through wildfire cases in two regions of Yunnan Province, offering scalable technical support for improving early detection of and rapid response to forest fires."
For more information on this research see: All-Weather Forest Fire Automatic Monitoring and Early Warning Application Based on Multi-Source Remote Sensing Data: Case Study of Yunnan. Fire, 2025,8(9):344. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8090344.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Boyang Gao, Key Laboratory of Sustainable Forest Ecosystem Management of Ministry of Education, College of Forestry, Northeast Forestry University, Harbin 150040, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Weiwei Jia, Qiang Wang, Guang Yang.
Keywords for this news article include: Northeast Forestry University, Harbin, People's Republic of China, Asia, Algorithms, Physics, Remote Sensing.

urn:contentItem:6GRW-S8K3-RXVG-23BK-00000-00Arequipa: more than 50 species of flora and fauna affected by forest fire in the foothills of Misti volcano2025-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisArequipa: more than 50 species of flora and fauna affected by forest fire in the foothills of Misti volcano

Arequipa: more than 50 species of flora and fauna affected by forest fire on the slopes of Misti volcanoAmong the flora species destroyed there are some at risk of extinction. Authorities blame land invaders for the fire.

INDECI issues emergency alert in Arequipa: forest fire is located in the foothills of Misti volcano

Wilder Pari
Serious ecological damage in Arequipa. A total of 50 species of flora and at least 7 species of fauna were affected by the forest fire that occurred last weekend on the slopes of Misti volcano, informed the technical administrator of Serfor, Felipe Gonzalez Dueñas.


The official detailed that in the area of the fire (high parts of the districts of Miraflores, Mariano Melgar and Chiguata) there are 50 species of flora, of which 15 are categorized with some type of threat and 8 are endemic to the area.
WE RECOMMEND YOUSin Guión | Phillip Butters in LR
In terms of fauna, the species affected are Andean foxes, partridges, eagles, small birds, lizards, wild guinea pigs and other rodents. It is worth mentioning that, although these animals have not been consumed by the fire, their habitat has been destroyed, so they end up displaced.
The Serfor official pointed out that the exact number of hectares devastated by the forest fire on Saturday and Sunday has not yet been calculated. Only in the first hours of the fire, 47 hectares were estimated, but the figure increased as the hours went by.
Invaders are suspected of causing the fire.
The district mayor of Miraflores, Germán Torres, suspects that the fire may have been started by land invaders. It should be noted that the flames started in this jurisdiction.
Torres said that land invaders usually burn grasslands to free the land. "There are people who want to invade and clean the space and burn the branches," he said.
The mayor asked the Regional Government of Arequipa to protect the slopes of the Misti volcano from human presence, remembering that they are high risk areas. At the moment, the encroachments continue to grow towards the volcano, some of them only 4 kilometers away.
New forest fire
The Regional Government of Arequipa informed that this September 15 a new small forest fire was registered in the high part of the district of Cayma, around 11:00 am. According to the entity, the fire was controlled by midday, but it is still being monitored.

urn:contentItem:6H3B-9H33-RW0T-82RM-00000-00New Findings on Engineering Described by Investigators at Dalian University of Technology (A New Weighted Rough Set and Improved Bp Neural Network Method for Predicting Forest Fires)2025-10-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisENGINEERINGNew Findings on Engineering Described by Investigators at Dalian University of Technology (A New Weighted Rough Set and Improved Bp Neural Network Method for Predicting Forest Fires)


2025 OCT 30 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Disease Prevention Daily -- Investigators publish new report on Engineering. According to news originating from Liaoning, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "To solve the quality problems of redundant risk elements, data imbalance, and noisy samples, which are commonly found in forest fire datasets, and to further improve the accuracy of forest fire risk prediction. In this paper, a forest fire prediction method is proposed, which combines a probability-weighted rough set attribute reduction (PWRS-AR) strategy with a particle swarm optimization improved BP neural network (PSO-I-BPNN) for forest fire prediction."


Financial support for this research came from National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC).
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from the Dalian University of Technology, "Firstly, a probabilistic weighted rough set attribute reduction method is designed to effectively eliminate non-critical and redundant features in the dataset and simplify the input space of the neural network. Subsequently, a particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm is employed to refine the BP neural network (BPNN), aiming to elevate both the precision and efficiency of forest fire prediction. To validate the method's effectiveness, experiments are conducted on three representative forest fire datasets."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The results show that compared with the traditional machine learning prediction methods, the proposed forest fire prediction model achieves a significant improvement in prediction accuracy and is more suitable for early warning and disaster prevention and mitigation strategies in forest fire-prone areas."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: A New Weighted Rough Set and Improved Bp Neural Network Method for Predicting Forest Fires. Reliability Engineering & System Safety, 2025;263. Reliability Engineering & System Safety can be contacted at: Elsevier Sci Ltd, 125 London Wall, London, England. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Reliability Engineering & System Safety - www.journals.elsevier.com/reliability-engineering-and-system-safety/)

Additional authors for this research include Ning Wang, Shibo Cui, Rui Zhao and Yongping Yu.

urn:contentItem:6H4V-7PJ3-S919-H0DB-00000-00Reports Outline Cloud Computing Findings from Kahramanmaras Sutcu Imam University (Evaluating Forest Fire Severity and Vegetative Recovery Using Sentinel Imagery and Spectral Indices In a Cloud-based Environment)2025-11-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisINFORMATION TECHNOLOGY - CLOUD COMPUTINGReports Outline Cloud Computing Findings from Kahramanmaras Sutcu Imam University (Evaluating Forest Fire Severity and Vegetative Recovery Using Sentinel Imagery and Spectral Indices In a Cloud-based Environment)


2025 NOV 06 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Information Technology Daily -- New research on Information Technology - Cloud Computing is the subject of a report. According to news reporting out of Kahramanmaras, Turkiye, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Factors such as global climate change, improper use of natural resources, and natural disasters have the potential to threaten wildlife habitat and human well-being. Recently disasters have had much more severe economic and ecological effects due to anthropogenic and other factors."


Financial support for this research came from TU BITAK BIDEB 2219 as part of the visiting scholar program.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Kahramanmaras Sutcu Imam University, "Large-scale wildfires, which are increasingly observed around the world, pose a major threat to all ecosystems. Wildfire analysis results have the potential to reduce negative economic, social, and ecological effects. We applied the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) and differenced Normalized Burn Ratio (dNBR) to evaluate vegetation recovery (VR) annually between 2020 and 2024 of an area impacted by the Holiday Farm Fire in Oregon (USA). Spectral index maps were created for 56 months using Sentinel-2 imagery on the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform. Index values were exported for a total of 191 sampling points that were systematically distributed within the fire area. NDVI and dNBR values were applied to classify recovery trends as either 'good', 'moderate' or 'poor'. Results revealed a 2024 heterogeneous VR distribution with 5.2 % of the study area classified as good', 64.4 % as 'moderate', 30.4 % as 'poor' and representing areas of slow or no NDVI recovery."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Our results indicated that the most moderate vegetative recovery was observed in the second half of 2022 (within two years of fire), especially in riparian zones with high severity burns."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Evaluating Forest Fire Severity and Vegetative Recovery Using Sentinel Imagery and Spectral Indices In a Cloud-based Environment. Advances in Space Research, 2025;76(8):4092-4105. Advances in Space Research can be contacted at: Elsevier Sci Ltd, 125 London Wall, London, England. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Advances in Space Research - www.journals.elsevier.com/advances-in-space-research/)

urn:contentItem:6GMP-VS73-RTKJ-1155-00000-00Türkiye's Fierce Forest Fire Reaches Residential Neighborhoods2025-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisTürkiye's Fierce Forest Fire Reaches Residential Neighborhoods

Link to Image

Link to Story

A severe forest fire in Denizli province, western Türkiye, has reached residential neighborhoods, burning houses and leading to widespread evacuations, authorities confirmed Monday.



Governor Omer Faruk Coskun reported that all available resources have been deployed and firefighting efforts are ongoing to bring the blaze under control.

The fire's spread into populated areas has prompted the evacuation of 84 households to safer locations, as officials prioritize public safety.

Patients at Buldan Chest Diseases Hospital and its nearby annex in the Buldan district were also evacuated as a precaution due to the advancing fire. Ambulances transferred those under treatment to hospitals in Denizli's city center, and a temporary medical tent was set up near the hospital to provide urgent care.

A video shared by local news platform Denizli Trafik Yasam showed flames driven by strong winds reaching residential zones, with residents fleeing in panic and trying to rescue their livestock from the fire.

The forest fire started on August 27 in the Buldan district of Denizli and spread across the provincial border into neighboring Aydin. After four days of burning along the Denizli-Aydin border, the fire was largely contained but reignited late Sunday night.

urn:contentItem:6GN4-5DG3-S59F-W0FW-00000-00Civil Defense reports one active forest fire in the country2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisCivil Defense reports one active forest fire in the country


In the midst of the deployment of personnel to the affected areas, the Vice Ministry of Civil Defense reported this Tuesday an active forest fire in the national territory. The fire has been identified in Ñembi Guasu, a conservation area located in the department of Santa Cruz.


"The only fire that we have at this moment registered as such, as a forest fire is in Ñembi Guasu, in the municipality of Charagua Yambae (...). We have a lot of personnel in the area", informed the Vice Minister of Civil Defense, Juan Carlos Calvimontes, in RTP.
The authority made a differentiation between forest fire and "active fire". In this sense, he indicated that fire outbreaks have been identified in other parts of the country, however, they are not classified as fires.
FOREST FIRE
"There is a presence of active fire, not necessarily fire, for example, in Beni, in San Ramón, it has been verified that it is the burning of pastures. We also have in Pando, Bolpebra, which is a product of chaqueo, unfortunately they are chaqueando", said Calvimontes.
The teams remain on alert. One of the most recent and serious emergencies occurred in Toro Toro, Potosí, where the death of one person was confirmed. President Luis Arce assured that this fire is already under control, an aspect that was corroborated by the Vice Minister.
"In Toro Toro the fire has already been completely put out. In Carmen Ribero Torrez and San Ignacio de Velasco, the fires are under control, we are in the cooling stage," he said.
In addition, the authority reported that, for Monday, the country closed the day with 1,462 hot spots, of which, most were recorded in the department of Santa Cruz, which had 684.
Calvimontes stressed that the situation in terms of forest fires is less than last year.
"August, which was the second most critical month in the 2024 management, Bolivia closed with 751,392 hot spots; and August, of the 2025 management we have closed with 53,199; that is almost 700,000 hot spots less than the previous management. And obviously this explains why at this moment there are no major fires, we are not experiencing a period of fires like the one we had experienced in 2022, 2023 and 2024", he stressed.
In 2024, fire devastated more than 10 million hectares in the country.
