urn:contentItem:6GR1-WSJ3-RRSM-62PV-00000-00Forest fire in Colomi is under control thanks to rapid intervention2025-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisForest fire in Colomi is under control thanks to rapid intervention


The forest fire that affected the municipality of Colomi, in the department of Cochabamba, was controlled this Thursday, September 11, 2025. This was achieved thanks to the rapid intervention of firefighters from the 26th Infantry Regiment "Juana Azurduy de Padilla". The action was carried out in coordination with personnel from the municipal Risk Management Unit (UGR) and the Governor's Office, which allowed the flames to be effectively smothered.


Samuel Pereira, coordinator of the Ministry of Defense in Cochabamba, informed that 50 military forest firefighters and 6 instructors were deployed to attend the emergency. He also explained that the operation was carried out by instruction of the Joint Command of Reaction to Adverse Events. The teams arrived in the community of Chullpani on the afternoon of Wednesday, September 10, and immediately began extinguishing the fire.
Damage caused by the fire
The fire consumed about 30 hectares, resulting in the destruction of quehuiña trees, grasses, shrubs and native species up to 2 meters high, which were reduced to ashes. If not controlled in time, the flames could have spread to other areas and caused greater damage.
Effective coordination
Pereira emphasized that the coordination between firefighters, the UGR and the Governor's Office was decisive in controlling the fire. He pointed out that this joint action prevented the fire from spreading and causing more damage in the region.
LDVY
The post Forest fire in Colomi is controlled thanks to quick intervention first appeared on Periódico La Patria.

urn:contentItem:6GNJ-3DS3-RS08-T03H-00000-00A forest fire is registered in the Ilaló mountain this September 3rd.2025-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisA forest fire is registered in the Ilaló mountain this September 3rd.


On Wednesday afternoon, September 3, 2025, a new forestfire was reported on Ilalóhill. The QuitoFire Department reported the emergency at 17:28 and deployed its teams to control the flames.
At 18:00, the institution detailed that the fire affects an area of bushes, shrubs and trees located on a slope of 80 degrees of inclination, which complicates the entry of the units.


Forest fires in Quito during 2025
The Fire Department told ELCOMERCIO that between July 1 and September 1, 2025, 15 forest fires were recorded in the Metropolitan District of Quito. These events affected 131 65 hectares of forests, grasslands and scrublands.
During the same period, 615 wasteburnings were also recorded, affecting 11.26 hectares.
Difference between forest fire and waste burning
Firefighters explained that a forest fire is a fire that spreads uncontrolled in naturalecosystems, causing environmental, social and economic damage.
The risk increases in interface zones, that is, in the limits between natural areas and populatedsectors, where the flames can compromisehousing, infrastructure and people's health.
In contrast, a waste burning consists of the combustion of urban, agricultural or mixed waste, such as garbage, branches, debris or plastics. Although in principle it does not constitute a forestfire, if it occurs near interface zones it can turn into one and cause emergencies of greatermagnitude.
High daytime temperatures can contribute to the formation of forest fires.
The MetropolitanEOC warns about the risk of heatstroke and dehydration, especially in vulnerablegroups due to high daytimetemperatures. Likewise, there may be higher consumption of water and electricity due to the use of cooling systems.
With these conditions, the probability of forestfiresincreases in some sectors, take precautions and do not burn in dry areas orlightsparks.
Ultravioletradiation remains at extremely high levels, so always use sunscreen.

Wear clothing that covers your skin, so you will be protected from radiation and the sun.

Always carry an umbrella, even if there is no rain, it can protect you from the sun.

Stay hydrated

Keep rooms cool and ventilated

Pay more attention to children and elderly people

urn:contentItem:6H34-BFT3-RSXV-P480-00000-00Investigators at Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Indore Discuss Findings in Sustainable Development [Forest Fires and Climate Change In India: Impacts, Adaptive Strategies, and Pathways for Climate Action (Sustainable Development Goal-13)]2025-10-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisSUSTAINABILITY RESEARCH - SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENTInvestigators at Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Indore Discuss Findings in Sustainable Development [Forest Fires and Climate Change In India: Impacts, Adaptive Strategies, and Pathways for Climate Action (Sustainable Development Goal-13)]


2025 OCT 29 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Investigators discuss new findings in Sustainability Research - Sustainable Development. According to news originating from Madhya Pradesh, India, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "India has been witnessing a rise in forest fire frequency and intensity due to climate change factors such as increasing temperatures, erratic rainfall, and prolonged droughts. These changes pose severe risks to biodiversity, carbon stocks, and forest-dependent communities, making assessing the climate change-forest fire relationship essential."


Financial support for this research came from King Saud University.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Indore, "This systematic review synthesizes evidence on climate change-induced forest fires in India, their ecological and socio-economic impacts, and current adaptation measures. Forests cover 21.67% of India's land, and 36% are prone to forest fire incidents. The literature revealed a strong correlation between increasing temperatures and increased forest fire events, especially in the Western Ghats, Himalayas, Northeastern region, and central India. Major ecological impacts comprise habitat loss, soil degradation, and increasing emissions of greenhouse gases, while socio-economic consequences vary from livelihood difficulties to health issues. Despite technological advancements in early warning systems, community involvement, policy integration, and resource limitations remain. The study demonstrates the necessity for climate-resilient forest fire management by promoting community-based adaptation, upgrading forest fire monitoring networks, and integrating forest fire risk assessment into climate action and Sustainable Development Goal-13 (SDG-13) plans are essential."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Addressing India's forest fire risk calls for an integrated approach combining scientific findings, reforms to policy, and community involvement, which is crucial for safeguarding India's ecosystems and vulnerable populations in a changing climatic scenario."
For more information on this research see: Forest Fires and Climate Change In India: Impacts, Adaptive Strategies, and Pathways for Climate Action (Sustainable Development Goal-13). Environmental Sciences Europe, 2025;37(1). Environmental Sciences Europe can be contacted at: Springer, One New York Plaza, Suite 4600, New York, Ny, United States. (BioMed Central - www.biomedcentral.com/; Environmental Sciences Europe - www.enveurope.com)
The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained from Amit Kumar, Indian Institute of Technology, School of Humanities and Social Sciences, Khandwa Rd, Indore 453552, Madhya Pradesh, India. Additional authors for this research include Tapas Ray, T. Mohanasundari, Surendra Singh Jatav, Uday Chatterjee, Sulochana Shekhar, Edris Alam and Md Kamrul Islam.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1186/s12302-025-01195-6. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6H1M-HF73-RSV0-53HH-00000-00Korea Water Resources Corporation Researchers Describe Advances in Environmental Science (Interception reduction from deforestation and forest fire increases large-scale fluvial flooding risk)2025-10-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisENVIRONMENT - ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCEKorea Water Resources Corporation Researchers Describe Advances in Environmental Science (Interception reduction from deforestation and forest fire increases large-scale fluvial flooding risk)


2025 OCT 22 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Data detailed on environmental science have been presented. According to news originating from the Korea Water Resources Corporation by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "Catastrophic flooding has been noted to occur with greater frequency following deforestation, but limited observations have been available to test this connection over large spatial scales."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Korea Water Resources Corporation: "Here we used the data of mega forest fires impacting a region of 25,000 km2 in Australia exhibiting rapid loss in forest canopy, where the runoff generation has been carefully observed with minimum anthropogenic influences for more than half a century. This provides a unique opportunity to assess the impact of the forest canopy loss on large-scale fluvial flooding. A state-controlled hypothesis test, with the climate and watershed states controlled to enhance robustness, shows a statistically significant increase in annual maximum flows resulting from the forest loss treatment."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The reasoning for this natural experiment is that the forest loss impact on the interception potential of forest canopy, fallen leaves, and root-zone soils in wide region could have a recognizable impact on the fluvial flood."
For more information on this research see: Interception reduction from deforestation and forest fire increases large-scale fluvial flooding risk. Communications Earth & Environment, 2025,6(1):1-9. The publisher for Communications Earth & Environment is Nature Portfolio.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1038/s43247-025-02748-6.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Tae-Ho Kang, Water Resources and Environmental Research Center, K-water Institute, Korea Water Resources Corporation. Additional authors for this research include Ashish Sharma, Lucy Marshall, Young-Oh Kim.
Keywords for this news article include: Korea Water Resources Corporation, Business, Climate Change, Deforestation, Environment, Environmental Science, Global Warming.

urn:contentItem:6GMP-MW33-RRHX-31WG-00000-00Forest fire in western Türkiye reaches homes, prompts evacuations2025-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSForest fire in western Türkiye reaches homes, prompts evacuationsZeynep Cermen

ISTANBUL, Sept. 1 (Xinhua) -- A forest fire in Denizli province, western Türkiye, reached residential areas, burning houses and prompting evacuations, authorities said on Monday. Governor Omer Faruk Coskun said on the social media platform X that all available resources had been mobilized and that efforts were continuing to bring the fire under control. He noted that 84 households had been evacuated to safe areas after the flames spread into residential zones. Türkiye's Ihlas News Agency reported that patients at Buldan Chest Diseases Hospital and its annex in the Buldan district were also evacuated as a precaution because of the advancing fire. Patients under treatment were transferred by ambulance to hospitals in downtown Denizli, while a field tent was set up near the hospital for urgent medical care, it added. A video shared on X by Denizli Trafik Yasam, a local news platform, showed flames fanned by strong winds reaching residential areas as people ran in panic. Many residents were also seen trying to save their livestock from the blaze. The forest fire, which began on Aug. 27 in Denizli's Buldan district, spread across the provincial border into neighboring Aydin. After burning for four days along the Denizli-Aydin border, it was largely contained but flared up again on Sunday night. Enditem

urn:contentItem:6GN4-5F03-S5NX-F0GT-00000-00Forest fire threatens Machupicchu's surroundings2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisForest fire threatens Machupicchu's surroundings

Listen to this note
A forest fire broke out on Monday, September 1, 2025, near the Historic Sanctuary of Machupicchu, generating concern about the proximity of the fire to the main access road for tourists.


The fire, which started in the Pacaymayo Bajo sector, at kilometer 96 of the railway line, does not pose an immediate threat to the Inca citadel, but it does pose a threat to the infrastructure that connects to the world wonder.
Although the fire started on Monday around 2:00 p.m., the containment response was limited by the night and the lack of personnel.
A team of six people from the National Service of Natural Areas Protected by the State (SERNANP) initially supported the work, but the magnitude of the fire, which spread to an adjacent hill, forced the suspension of operations until dawn the following day.
Image Celebrities Tue, 02/09/2025 - 09:14 Enrique Iglesias confirms he will be a father for the fourth time
At the age of 50, the artist will be a father for the fourth time with Russian tennis player Anna Kournikova.
Very Navarro
For Tuesday, September 2, 2025, a massive response has been coordinated. Early in the morning, forest fire departments from SERNANP and the Ministry of Culture went to the site of the incident.
A total of 25 people from SERNANP, coming from different areas such as Piscacucho and Machupicchu Pueblo, joined the work, together with 15 members of the Ministry of Culture.
Coordination between authorities has been constant since the fire was reported. The Office of Disaster Risk Management of the District Municipality of Machupicchu has been in communication with both entities to manage the transportation of the brigades and the necessary equipment, including hand tools and water backpacks.
Three members of the Peruvian National Police have also reportedly been deployed.
The risk of forest fires in Cusco is a latent threat to the ecosystem and cultural heritage. It is expected that, with the intervention of specialized brigades, the flames will be controlled to protect the natural environment and tourist infrastructure in the area.

urn:contentItem:6GRW-3CH3-RRKR-6282-00000-00Authorities attend forest fire in the province of Arequipa2025-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisAuthorities attend forest fire in the province of Arequipa

Emergency began in the foothills of the Misti volcano and covers the districts of Miraflores, Mariano Melgar and ChiguataPress note No. 411-2025

The National Institute of Civil Defense (INDECI), through the National Emergency Operations Center (COEN), reports that local authorities carry out the response actions before the forest fire initiated this morning in the foothills of the Misti Volcano and covers the districts of Miraflores, Mariano Melgar and Chiguata of the province and department of Arequipa.

In this regard, the district municipalities together with members of the General Corps of Volunteer Firefighters of Peru and inhabitants carried out control and extinction work of fire; work that will resume tomorrow Sunday, September 14 due to the difficult access to the area.

For its part, the Provincial Municipality of Arequipa and Regional Government coordinate with the Risk Management Offices of the municipalities involved and first response entities, the actions to continue with emergency care.

At the moment, 48 hectares of natural coverage are recorded; Likewise, no damage to peoples life and health is reported. Damage evaluation and needs analysis (EDAN) continues in process.

Indeci, through the National Emergency Operations Center (COEN), continues to monitor these types of events that are registered in different regions, in coordination with the regional, provincial and district emergency operations centers, as well as with the respective authorities the response actions.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G1B3-RS6X-V0BV-00000-00Firefighters of Guayaquil attend a forest fire this Friday, August 22nd.2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisFirefighters of Guayaquil attend a forest fire this Friday, August 22nd.


The Fire Brigade of Guayaquil attends this Friday, August 22, an alarm three for a forest fire in Ciudad Victoria, northwest of Guayaquil.
Forest fire
After the alert for a forest fire, the Fire Department of Guayaquil coordinated actions to attend the emergency and control the flames to prevent them from spreading.


For this purpose, the institution dispatched a contingent of 17 units, including firefighting units, tankers, forestry trucks and a tanker truck.
The causes of the forest fire are not known; however, citizens are advised not to burn or light sparks in forest areas.
Remember that Inamhi warned about favorable weather conditions for the formation and spread of fires. If you see a column of smoke, call 911 immediately.
450 forest fires in 2025
The National Secretariat of Risk Management (SNGR) reported that from January 1 to August 20, 2025, 450 forest fires were registered in Ecuador.
These were located in 18 provinces, 72 cantons and 212 parishes and caused the loss of 2,242.08 hectares (ha) of vegetation cover.
The provinces most affected are:

Imbabura with 1 164.89 ha.

Chimborazo with 344.70 hectares (344.70 ha)

Loja with 139 ha

Guayas with 136.94 ha

Pichincha with 98.13 ha

Santa Elena with 61 ha


These fires left one person affected in Ecuador and a BRIF has been activated in Quito to help control the fire in the Cotacachi fire.
The forest fire in the Cotacachi-Cayapas Reserve is the only large-scale fire active in Ecuador on August 22 and continues to spread.

urn:contentItem:6GS3-RCG3-RSGF-H393-00000-00Mayor of Miraflores accuses invaders of forest fire on Misti volcano2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisMayor of Miraflores accuses invaders of forest fire on Misti volcano


Alleged land invaders are said to have caused the forest fire on the slopes of the Misti volcano, which started on September 13 in the district of Miraflores and spread for almost 24 hours, also reaching sectors of Mariano Melgar and Chiguata.


The mayor of Miraflores, Germán Torres, assured that during the emergency there were indications that strange people were delimiting lands in the high part with stones and fire. "When we went to the place we found families that were clearing the brush to invade. We even identified several people with tools, which has already been reported to the Police so that investigations can be carried out", he said.
The mayor added that this is not the first time that there have been attempts of invasion in the area and requested the intervention of regional and national authorities to stop the advance of land traffickers.
The hypothesis of arson was also confirmed by the National Forestry and Wildlife Service (Serfor). Serfor's technical administrator in Arequipa, Luis Felipe Gonzáles Dueñas, reported that Serfor personnel confirmed the presence of delimited areas and fire outbreaks in areas that were difficult to access, which reinforces the suspicion of invasion.
Serfor can impose administrative fines of up to 10 UIT, in addition to the corresponding criminal sanctions. "Not only was there a logistical and personnel expense to put out the fire, but also a human risk. We will be drastic in the sanctions if those responsible are identified," he said.
Diego Ayca, Deputy Manager of Risk and Disaster Management of the Provincial Municipality of Arequipa (MPA), informed yesterday that about 300 hectares were affected by the forest fire. The strong winds in the area caused it to spread easily.
According to Serfor, the fire devastated a high Andean ecosystem of scrub and grassland, affecting at least 50 species of flora. According to the National Forestry and Wildlife Service (SERFOR), 15 of them are categorized as vulnerable and eight are endemic to the region, such as the cahuato (Tecoma arequipensis).
Regarding the fauna, Luis Felipe Gonzáles Dueñas, Technical Forestry and Wildlife Administrator in Arequipa, indicated that the exact number of species affected has not yet been determined, but traces of Andean foxes, partridges, lizards and wild guinea pig shelters have been identified, in addition to birds whose nests were consumed by the fire.

urn:contentItem:6GNJ-3DY3-RS5H-302J-00000-00Rains and brigadistas manage to control forest fire in Machu Picchu2025-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisRains and brigadistas manage to control forest fire in Machu Picchu

Rains and brigade members manage to control forest fire in Machu PicchuAfter almost three days, the fire affected 15 hectares of vegetation in the Pacaymayo Bajo sector. No damage to the population or property was reported.

Forest fire near Machu Picchu keeps alert active in Cusco

Luis Álvarez
Thanks to the work of more than 40 brigadiers from Sernanp and the Decentralized Direction of Culture of Cusco, added to a persistent drizzle that fell in the valley, it was possible to control the forest fire that started on September 1 in the Pacaymayo Bajo sector, at kilometer 96.5 of the Ollantaytambo-Machupicchu railroad in Cusco.


The fire consumed approximately 15 hectares of shrub vegetation in an area of difficult access, with slopes of up to 80 degrees. According to the official report, there was no damage to houses, crops, livelihoods or cultural heritage.
The fire, which had originated near the Inca citadel, generated alarm among the population and local and regional authorities. "Fortunately the fire was controlled and in the next few hours we will have the report of its definitive liquidation," said Miguel Angel Oscco, director of the Regional Emergency Operations Center (COER) Cusco.
The brigades remain in the area monitoring and liquidating the last outbreaks, in addition to an evaluation of damages and needs. Until the closing of this information, the fighters were going to smoke points to prevent the fire from rekindling.
A joint effort
The emergency was attended under the Unified Command System, with logistical support from the District Municipality of Machupicchu and the transfer of brigade members provided by PeruRail. The rain, which persisted in the valley, was decisive for the flames to subside and the fire could be controlled.
So far this year, 160 forest fires have been reported in the region, which have affected more than 4,000 hectares of vegetation. "Although the figures are lower compared to last year - 8,000 hectares destroyed in 360 fires - the situation is still worrying," Oscco added.

urn:contentItem:6GPT-XJ03-SGRP-9174-00000-00Cusco: elderly adult dies trapped in the middle of a forest fire2025-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisCusco: elderly adult dies trapped in the middle of a forest fire

Cusco: senior citizen dies trapped in the middle of a forest fireCancio Maqui Lima, 73 years old, tried to save his cattle in Chumbivilcas, but the fire reached him. He became the second fatality so far this year.

Rains and brigadiers manage to control forest fire in Machu Picchu

Luis Álvarez
The smoke rising over the fields of the community of Antuyo Llaullimarca, in the district of Llusco, province of Chumbivilcas, in Cusco, alerted its inhabitants. Don Cancio Maqui Lima, 73 years old, was desperately trying to protect his cattle from the fire, which, according to his neighbors, he had accidentally started.


A spark from his cigarette had fallen on the dry grass, starting a fire that soon got out of control. The elderly man's intention was to rescue his cow, but the flames advanced uncontrollably faster. Trapped in the middle of the fire, he suffered severe burns that took his life.
His departure saddens the entire farming community, which remembers him as a hard-working man dedicated to his animals.
"We deeply regret the death of this elderly man, who becomes the second fatal victim of forest fires so far in 2025," said the director of the Regional Office of Disaster Risk Management, Miguel Oscco Abarca. The first case occurred in May, in the district of Lucre.
Losses from forest fires
The figures reveal the magnitude of the problem: so far this year there have been 190 fires in Cusco, with almost 5 thousand hectares of vegetation destroyed. In September alone, 21 fires have been reported.
"The death of Don Cancio is a painful reminder that burns, no matter how small or everyday they may seem, can unleash irreparable tragedies," added Miguel Oscco.

urn:contentItem:6GRR-VG93-RXKY-338Y-00000-00U�€™khand govt submits action plan on forest fire prevention2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisDEHRADUNU�€™khand govt submits action plan on forest fire preventionPankul Sharma

Dehradun: Following Uttarakhand high court's directions, the forest department on Monday submitted an action plan to prevent forest fires in the state. It also sought more time to comply with earlier orders, including filling vacant posts within six months, strengthening village councils, and ensuring year-round forest monitoring.

The high court, hearing multiple public interest litigations on forest fires, granted the govt more time and scheduled the next hearing for next week. It also asked whether artificial rain was feasible in the state's geographical conditions and sought a detailed plan.

Despite the court issuing guidelines in 2016 for forest fire prevention, no committees were formed at the village level to tackle fires. The court noted that helicopters were being used to fight fires�€”a costly and ineffective approach�€”and said village-level committees would be a more efficient solution.

The court had taken suo motu cognisance of the matter in 2018 after a PIL was filed on the issue. Since then, it has repeatedly directed the state govt to act, but most decisions remained on paper. Advocates Dushyant Mainali and Rajeev Bisht had earlier informed the court that many forests across Uttarakhand continued to burn with no substantial measures taken by the state.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-4G83-RTX7-G39T-00000-00Rain helped control forest fire in Machu Picchu Archaeological Park2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisRain helped control forest fire in Machu Picchu Archaeological Park


According to the last emergency report, issued by the Office of Disaster Risk Management of the District Municipality of Machu Picchu (Cusco), the forest fire that had started on Monday in the area, could finally be controlled last Wednesday afternoon.


The strong fire that started in the sector of Pacaymayo bajo, at kilometer 96.500 of the railway line to Machu Picchu, consumed so far 13 hectares of natural pastures, within the Archaeological Park of Machu Picchu.
Authorities confirmed that the forest fire did not affect archeological remains nor did it reach the world wonder, despite being inside the park, located approximately five kilometers from the sanctuary.
According to the Machu Picchu authorities' information alert, forestry fighters from Cultura, Sernanp, and Indeci are still at the site in order to completely eliminate the fire.
"There is presence of drizzle in the sector in the early morning of today (Wednesday) so far, which has helped to control the fire. Crews have remained monitoring the event until its liquidation, given that there are still scattered smoke in areas of difficult access", a last report of the event quotes textually.
It was learned that the fire does not affect train operations to and from the world wonder, while the company Perurail is moving logistics and forestry fighters to different points of the railway in order to completely liquidate the fire.

urn:contentItem:6GKF-BMF3-S7JF-T39B-00000-00Autonomous Forest Fire Detection, Alerting and Mitigation for Communities2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisAutonomous Forest Fire Detection, Alerting and Mitigation for CommunitiesTargeted News ServiceAlexandria, Va.

ALEXANDRIA, Virginia, Aug. 26 -- Two inventors, Rhea Rawat, Edison, New Jersey, and Ritika Rawat, Edison, New Jersey, have been awarded a patent (No. US 12397183 B1, initially filed March 14, 2025) for "Autonomous forest fire detection, alerting and mitigation for communities."

Various embodiments for an autonomous forest fire detection, alerting and mitigation device includes a subterranean data gatherer having a plurality of soil temperature and soil moisture sensors installed at a plurality of different depths in a soil. A data assimilator that has a configured threshold change depending on the plurality of different depths in the soil of the plurality of soil temperature and soil moisture sensors, the soil properties, the duration of the fire, and a time delay duration. The data assimilator receives a data transmission packet from the subterranean data gatherer and detects a fire and generates a fire alert when the plurality of soil temperature and soil moisture sensors all breach the configured threshold change. A smart water pump is also started to slow the fire or completely stop it. The subterranean data gatherer is installed at the plurality of different depths in the soil.

urn:contentItem:6GRN-SV73-RXRC-J2MF-00000-00Arequipa: forest fire in the Misti foothills affects more than 40 hectares of natural forest cover2025-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisArequipa: forest fire in the Misti foothills affects more than 40 hectares of natural forest cover


A forest fire broke out on the morning of Saturday, September 13 in the foothills of the Misti volcano, in the province of Arequipa, affecting the districts of Miraflores, Mariano Melgar and Chiguata.


According to the National Civil Defense Institute (INDECI), through the National Emergency Operations Center (COEN), at least 48 hectares of natural cover were destroyed. No damage to life or health was reported.
The district municipalities, together with members of the fire department and the local population, carried out fire control and extinguishing works. This work will continue during the morning of Sunday, September 14.
According to official information updated up to 7:30 p.m. last Saturday, 40 hectares were destroyed by the fire in the district of Miraflores, five in the district of Mariano Melgar and three in the district of Chiguata.
The Provincial Municipality of Arequipa and the regional government are coordinating with the Risk Management Offices of the municipalities involved and first response entities, the actions to continue with the emergency response.
Immediate actions demanded
The Ombudsman's Office demanded immediate actions and coordination by the Regional Emergency Operations Center (COER) of Arequipa to control and mitigate the forest fire in the foothills of Misti volcano.
The entity requested the formation of brigades with logistical equipment in order to prevent the fire from reaching homes and causing damage to people.
For its part, the Provincial Municipality of Arequipa asked the population to remain calm, not to approach the area of the fire and to follow the recommendations of Civil Defense.

urn:contentItem:6GS3-RCC3-RS97-72X8-00000-00Arequipa: Forest fire destroys 120 hectares of pastureland in Caylloma2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisArequipa: Forest fire destroys 120 hectares of pastureland in Caylloma

Listen to this note
A forest fire of great magnitude broke out on the night of Monday, September 15 in the district of Tisco, province of Caylloma, affecting at least 120 hectares of natural cover, according to information from the Civil Defense.


Imagen Perú Tue, 16/09/2025 - 11:37 Humanitarian train evacuates stranded tourists after clashes and blockades in Machu Picchu
A special convoy transferred visitors to Ollantaytambo after the protests in Coriwayrachina, which left more than a dozen injured. Hundreds of national and foreign travelers are still waiting to leave the area.
Pierre Jeanneau
The fire was reported at 7:10 p.m. yesterday by the district municipality of Tisco and immediately the Regional Emergency Operations Center (COER Arequipa) started monitoring the emergency and deployed a technical team to support the control work.
During the early morning, brigade members, municipal personnel and local residents worked intensely to quell the flames, which were reactivating in different areas due to the terrain and wind conditions. Finally, around 8:00 a.m. today, the fire was declared under control, informed the Regional Management of Disaster Risk Management.
So far, no damage to life or health has been reported. However, the Damage Evaluation and Needs Analysis (EDAN) is still active to determine the environmental and agricultural losses caused.
The Regional Government of Arequipa, through the COER and the GRD, reiterated that it will continue to report on the evolution of the emergency and highlighted the quick response of the community, which together with the authorities managed to mitigate the impact of the fire in this high Andean area of Caylloma.

urn:contentItem:6GSC-TYT3-RRSN-G4GD-00000-00Autonomous University of Barcelona: Horses, Possible Allies in Forest Fire Prevention2025-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisAutonomous University of Barcelona: Horses, Possible Allies in Forest Fire PreventionTargeted News ServiceBARCELONA, Spain

(TNSjou) -- The Autonomous University of Barcelona issued the following news:

* * *

Horses, possible allies in forest fire prevention

Horses play a key role in forest management and in reducing the risk of wildfires in Mediterranean forests, thanks to the adaptability of their eating habits. This is the conclusion reached by an interdisciplinary study led by the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona (UAB) and the University of Lleida (UdL), recently published in the journal Agroforestry Systems.

The research-which included the participation of Boumort Wildland, the Miranda Foundation, the Forest Horses association, and the University of Barcelona (UB)-reveals that horses adapt their diet according to breed, environment and use. This flexibility helps them play a complementary role alongside other herbivores in sustainable fire prevention strategies, given that their grazing reduces fuel loads and maintains open landscapes. The study was co-authored by researchers from the Department of Animal and Food Science at the UAB Jordi Bartolome and Araceli Gort-Esteve.

"Until now research on extensive herding and forest fire prevention has focused mainly on sheep and goats, with some isolated studies done on breeds of rustic cattle. There have been very few studies on horses within this context, since traditionally they are classified as plant grazers that have little effect on woody vegetations", explains Ariadna Nieto-Espinet, Ramon y Cajal researcher at the UdL and zooarchaeologist. "Our work is one of the first to use empirical data to analyse their potential in forest management in the Mediterannean", she adds.

The study analysed three specific cases with the aim of exploring the potential of horses in clearing forest undergrowth. At the Boumort National Game Reserve, the Przewalski's horses live in semi-freedom in a mosaic landscape with a low herd count of 0.02 animals per hectare (ha) and year. At the Garraf Natural Park, the rustic Pottoka horses continuously grazed and also roamed in semi-freedom during one year, with a low herd demography (0.2 animals/ha/year). The third case examined crossbred horses grazing for short periods of time, with supplementary food and a high animal count (2.5 animals/ha for the duration of one and a half months).

The team analysed the horses' diet based on 50 fresh faecal samples. "We used microhistological analysis of plant epidermis in faeces and advanced statistical models to obtain a precise assessment of the shifts in diet of these animals", specifies Araceli Gort-Esteve, researcher at the UAB and the Institute for Game and Wildlife Research (IREC-CSIC). Among the species found were woody plants of the Quercus, Juniperus and Pistacia genera, and other herbaceous species such as the Mediterranean false brome (Brachypodium retusum).

The results indicate that Przewalski's wild horses, in a mosaic landscape with patches of forest, scrub, and meadows, keep the fields cleared throughout the year by eating mainly grasses, with little impact on woody vegetation. Rustic breeds, such as the Pottoka, adapt to long periods of grazing by initially consuming fine, highly flammable grasses, and then moving on to woody plants as the grasses are depleted. They effectively manage both fine and coarse fuels, contributing to the control of the undergrowth. Finally, crossbred horses, subjected to intensive short-term grazing with supplementary feeding, quickly move from fine fuels to woody plants, demonstrating their potential for targeted management actions.

"The results with Pottoka and crossbred horses clearly show that horses, considered grazers with a preference for grasses, can quickly adapt to available resources, including woody species. This flexibility makes them a valuable resource for fire prevention strategies in Mediterranean landscapes, complementary to sheep and goats," says UAB lecturer Jordi Bartolome Filella. "Rustic breeds, often less valued today, have a great adaptive capacity that makes them key in silvopastoral tasks. Our study shows that horses can not only contribute to undergrowth control, but also to the maintenance of open spaces and mosaic landscapes," adds Ariadna Nieto-Espinet.

The research team agrees that more long-term studies are needed to quantify the direct impact of horses on reducing flammable biomass. Nevertheless, they believe that their dietary adaptability could make them a promising tool in more sustainable forest management strategies, especially in a context of climate change, rural depopulation, and increased risk of fires.

Original article: Gort-Esteve, A., Filella, J.B., Molinero, X.R. et al. Dietary strategies of feral and domestic horses under varying grazing pressures: insights for Mediterranean forest management. Agroforest Syst 99, 208 (2025). https://doi.org/10.1007/s10457-025-01291-9

urn:contentItem:6GR7-VNS3-RRPC-G3WK-00000-00Peasants of El Patía, Cauca, fight against gigantic forest fire in the Pan de Azúcar sector2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisPeasants of El Patía, Cauca, fight against gigantic forest fire in the Pan de Azúcar sector


Farmers from the rural area of the municipality of El Patía, in the south of Cauca, have been fighting for three days against a gigantic forest fire in the area known as Pan de Azúcar, in the rural area of this town.


"In an act of courage and true resistance, the peasants of the Pan de Azúcar sector, in what we call here the Patia mountain range, fight tirelessly to counteract a forest fire of great magnitude that threatens to devastate the vegetation and put at risk several families of this place", expressed journalists of this area of the country when indicating that the forest fire started last September 9.
Therefore, armed only with rudimentary tools such as shovels, machetes and branches, the inhabitants of this area in the south of the department have been forced to face the flames by themselves in the absence of immediate support from relief agencies.
"As it is an area where there is a presence of armed groups outside the law, the firefighters can't even go there, and they don't have the adequate tools, let alone vehicles, to face this kind of emergency, so now the people themselves are the ones who try to put out the fire with the means they have at hand", added the journalists.
Hence, this emergency is causing anguish among the inhabitants of Pan de Azúcar, who denounce that the fire is advancing rapidly, driven by the strong summer and the winds characteristic of the mountainous region.
For this reason, in the last hours, the inhabitants launched an urgent call to the municipal, departmental and national governments, requesting the presence of firefighters, Civil Defense and other risk management entities that can intervene with machinery and specialized equipment to stop the emergency.
"We are not leaving the place, we have to protect the houses and crops", commented Julio Gómez, a farmer of the area, who together with his neighbors, is now trying to save what little they have left, while others risked crossing through the fire to rescue people who are reported to be trapped in the middle of the flames.
As a result of this, and seeking to expedite the aid, the villagers shared a video on social networks and in the media for the authorities to support them in this place, seeking to protect the bread crops that exist in Pan de Azúcar.

urn:contentItem:6GM2-96F3-RSY7-J47N-00000-00Firefighters were able to extinguish forest fire in Quito2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisFirefighters were able to extinguish forest fire in Quito


A forest fire affected this Thursday morning, August 28, 2025, the Rayocucho sector, in the parish of Calacalí, in the northwest of the Metropolitan District of Quito. Specialized personnel went to the site to control the flames and prevent them from spreading.


Forest fire was registered in Quito on August 28th.
The response units were able to quell the fire after intense work in the affected area. Then, the teams carried out cooling and liquidation tasks to prevent the reactivation of hot spots. These actions seek to ensure that the emergency does not resurface as the hours go by.
The authorities reminded the public that setting forest fires is a crime punishable under Ecuadorian law.
Penalties for those who start forest fires
According to current regulations, those who start fires in forest areas face fines of up to 35,250 pesos. In aggravated cases, those responsible can receive prison sentences.
Forest fires cause irreparable damage to the environment, affect native fauna, destroy protected vegetation, and endanger the lives of nearby communities. They also pose a direct threat to personnel who risk their safety during control operations.
Forest risk prevention
In the face of these risks, the authorities called for citizen collaboration. If someone observes a person starting a fire in forest areas, they should immediately alert ECU 911.
During the dry season, forest fires increase considerably. Therefore, response entities maintain active monitoring protocols in vulnerable areas of the District and other provinces.
Citizen commitment is key in the prevention of this type of emergencies. Not lighting bonfires, not throwing lit cigarette butts and reporting suspicious behavior are minimal actions that can protect thousands of hectares of forest.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-4G53-RTHS-X490-00000-00Forest fire victim, tapir rescued in Teodoro Sampaio dies during treatment in Assis2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisForest fire victim, tapir rescued in Teodoro Sampaio dies during treatment in Assis


Despite undergoing intensive treatment at Apass (Wild Animal Protection Association) in Assis, the adult female tapir rescued on August 21 in the surroundings of the Morro do Diabo State Park in Teodoro Sampaio couldn't resist the injuries she suffered and died. The information was released on Tuesday by the state government, which named the case as the 17th official record of a wild animal victim of a forest fire in 2025. A ferret, a hedgehog and a deer have also died as a result of burns suffered in São Paulo this year.


As reported in this newspaper, the tapir's case was the first officially reported by a center accredited by Semil (Secretariat for the Environment, Infrastructure and Logistics) of a wild animal victim of a forest fire this year. After being rescued, the animal had first-, second- and third-degree burns on around 70% of its body, total loss of sight and a compromised ear, factors that had already determined that it would not be possible to return it to the wild.
The rescue was carried out by park rangers, together with the Environmental Military Police and several volunteers. The tapir was found weakened, with serious injuries, inside a dam in the middle of a sugarcane field. It is suspected that the injuries were caused by a fire on August 17, in the Morro do Diabo region - the only event recorded last month. Thus, the tapir would have remained injured for at least five days, without care, until it reached the dam.

urn:contentItem:6GNS-2DH3-RRWT-K3YV-00000-00A forest fire forces the evacuation of houses in Estepona and some are affected.2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisA forest fire forces the evacuation of houses in Estepona and some are affected.


A forest fire in Estepona (Malaga) has caused this Friday the eviction of several houses and has affected some of them and vehicles, although it has already been stabilized, according to municipal sources and the Andalusian fire plan Infoca.


Municipal sources have assured EFE that the eviction of several dozen homes has been temporary and preventive, given the strength of the wind blowing in the area and that at least four properties would have been affected in the area of the porch, exterior enclosure or garden.
The fire started in the place Valle Pederín about 14:20 hours and has been stabilized at 16:50 hours after the intervention of three helicopters (one heavy, one semi-heavy and one light) of Infoca, four groups of forest firefighters, two brigades BRICA and a fire truck.
From the Emergency Coordination Center 112 Andalusia have indicated to EFE that received numerous calls alerting of a fire in the Parque Antena urbanization very close to houses, so they acted firefighters, Infoca, Local Police and Civil Protection and that some of the operatives gave account of pergolas of houses affected.
For its part, the Provincial Fire Consortium has indicated that about 20 people were evacuated without damage, four vehicles were burned, several homes were affected, mainly in pergolas and facades, and a garage with a car inside has great structural affectation.
Three groups of forest firefighters and two brigades BRICA, according to the Infoca.
A forest fire in Estepona (Malaga) on Friday has caused the eviction of several homes and has affected some of them and vehicles externally, although it has already been stabilized, according to municipal sources and the Andalusian fire plan Infoca.

Vaduz, Liechtenstein: Liechtenstein State Administration has issued the following news release:

The Forest Fire Task Force is a nationwide organization composed of members of fire departments and mountain rescue teams, as well as forestry employees. Their task is to fight forest fires, particularly in steep terrain. This year's course, led by course commander Roland Biedermann from Ruggell, will take place on Saturday, September 13, 2025, in Triesenberg.

Since the number of members has steadily declined since the group's founding, an introductory course will be held again this year. The 26 course participants will learn the basics of forest fires and be made aware of the dangers they face. The tasks and working methods of the task force form another short theoretical block. In the much more extensive practical section, participants will learn about extinguishing equipment and the various extinguishing techniques used in forest fires. An introduction to safety techniques, which is essential when operating in steep and impassable terrain, is also very important, as the safety of the participants is, of course, paramount.

The theoretical lessons take place at the new Triesenberg Fire Department depot. For the practical lessons, participants go to various worksites in the surrounding forests.

urn:contentItem:6GP6-0J33-RT5S-N3FT-00000-00Arequipa: Forest fire in Cotahuasi continues and devastated 200 hectares2025-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:08ZLexisNexisArequipa: Forest fire in Cotahuasi continues and devastated 200 hectares


The forest fire affecting Cotahuasi, in the province of La Unión, continues to be active and has already destroyed more than 200 hectares of natural cover. In response to the emergency, the Regional Emergency Operations Center (COER) Arequipa and the Disaster Risk Management Manager, José Luis Barrezueta, went to the jurisdiction.


According to information provided by Barrezueta, the fire in and around Fundo El Huambo was brought under control so that the flames would not continue in Quillunsa and Allhuay. However, the fire still persists in the upper part of the estate, which is an area inaccessible to humans.
"The upper part is still missing, but the fire is no longer at a high level, and there are rocks there, there is no longer fauna as in the El Huambo farm, which will slow down the fire. The National Service of Natural Areas Protected by the State (Sernanp) is already taking care of this part (...) We have already managed to suffocate the part where there is housing, which is the ranch," he said.
Likewise, he explained that no damage to life or health of people was reported. It should be remembered that on Friday, September 5, the fire started in the sectors of Huambo, and until yesterday the affected hectares were 100 hectares. The residents, municipality and other officials of the Regional Government of Arequipa, went with water tanks to quench the fire.
